description: The park's primary visitor center provides an orientation of the park's roads, trails, and human and natural history. The interior exhibit space provides a glimpse of the diverse ecosystems and cultural heritage of the park. Audio-visual programs, shown in the auditorium, are available upon request. Natural history books, cards, and posters are for sale in the bookstore. Beach fire permits may be obtained here.
audioDescription: The Bear Valley Visitor Center is located in a fairly flat meadow at the base of a wooded ridge that rises to the west. Some of the western part of the meadow serves as a fenced horse pasture. The Bear Valley Visitor Center was constructed to resemble a large barn and is painted gray. Inside the visitor center are a bookstore, an information desk, an auditorium, and museum exhibits. On the right just before one passes through the visitor center's front double doors is a hallway leading to the restrooms. As one enters the visitor center, the bookstore is immediately to one's left, the information desk ahead and to the left, the entrance to the auditorium immediately beyond the information desk, and the museum exhibits to the right. The museum exhibits contain taxidermied animals and exhibits about the park's major ecosystems, including coastal wetlands, coastal shorelines, coastal grasslands, forests, and open ocean. There are also exhibits about human history at Point Reyes.
passportStampLocationDescription: The Point Reyes National Seashore Passport Stamp may be found inside the Bear Valley Visitor Center at the information desk. Check operating hours to know when to arrive so that the visitor center will be open.

emailAddresses.description:
Please browse through our website (the Plan Your Visit section is very useful) and check out the Frequently Asked Questions before submitting your message. We receive a lot of emails requesting information that is available through our website. 

We will respond to emails in the order they are received as soon as possible. Due to the high volume of email, response to your message may take more than a week. Please ensure that the email address you provide is correct.

directionsInfo: The Bear Valley Visitor Center is located approximately 30 miles (50 km) north of San Francisco, less than 1 mile off of Highway 1 along Bear Valley Road. Travelers may approach the park via the winding scenic Highway 1, either from the north or the south. Visitors can also reach the park via Sir Francis Drake Boulevard or the Point Reyes/Petaluma Road.

operatingHours.description:
Until further notice, the Bear Valley Visitor Center is scheduled to be open daily from 9:30 am until 5 pm.

The Bear Valley Visitor Center is closed on December 25 and may close at 2 pm on Thanksgiving and Christmas Eve.
operatingHours.name: Bear Valley Visitor Center

description: The Big Oak Flat Information Station has an information desk, wilderness permit desk, and Yosemite Conservancy Bookstore. In the winter, self-registration wilderness permits for the Crane Flat area and Tioga Road trailheads only, are available on the front porch. You must bring your own bear canister when the information station is closed. Wilderness permits are required for overnight stays in Yosemite's Wilderness. Designated accessible parking spaces are available in front of the facility.
audioDescription: The Big Oak Flat Information Station building is a one-story, long, modular trailer. An accessible ramp ascends across the length of the front of the building onto a deck. A brown metal sign at the top of the ramp reads Big Oak Flat Information Station and has a National Park Service logo. It goes on to read: visitor information, with an icon of a question mark, wilderness permits, with an icon of a person hiking, and bookstore, with an icon of an open book. On the deck, near the side entrance to the information station are two large, grey, metal bins that look like trash bins. Similar signs on both bins read: No trash, bear canister rental return, with an illustration of a bears' head. Next to the information station are restrooms and vending machines, with similar architectural features.

description: Located in the heart of beautiful Black Rock Campground. Bookstore, water, flush toilets, picnic area.
audioDescription: The Black Rock Nature Center is nestled in the heart of the Black Rock Campground, surrounded to the east, south, and west by the Little San Bernardino Mountains with dense forests of Joshua trees all around. The main campground road leads south from the entrance to a small parking area in front of a single-story rectangular building with a low peaked roof. The building is painted pale yellow and the roof has bright red shingles. There is a set of 6 stairs with a center handrail that lead up to the building’s entrance. The building may also be accessed without stairs by using a sidewalk on the west side. The entrance to the building is a single swinging door that opens out. The entrance door leads to a hallway. On the right side of the hallway is a counter where rangers greet visitors and provide information. On the left is a closed door that leads to a conference room and a large map mounted to the wall showing trails in the area. After the counter on the right is the entrance to a small gift shop that sells books and souvenirs. After the entrance to the gift shop on the right is a display window with information about the current exhibit. Past the display window and also on the right is a water fountain and bottle fill station. Across from the display window, on the left side of the entry way is a bench with 2 seats separated by a low table and another closed door that leads to the conference room. The entry way has an exit door opposite the entrance door which opens out to a sandy staff parking area. Passing straight through the gift shop is a small gallery. The walls and ceiling are made of wooden planks, art is displayed on white exhibit boards. There is a low bench with three seats in the center of the room. The gallery changes three times a year to feature work from the park’s artists in residence and local students. Continuing straight through the gallery along the right-hand wall is a low ramp with a handrail on the left side. Up the ramp and to the left is a hallway with two single occupancy bathrooms on the left side of the hallway.

description: This visitor center is next to the South Fork of the Kings River in mixed conifer forest at an elevation of 4,600 feet (1,400 m). Learn about the natural and cultural history of the Cedar Grove area. Nearby services include accessible restrooms and a pay phone.
audioDescription: A small building is surrounded by incense-cedar and small, young sequoia trees. Needles from the trees cover the ground, forming a reddish carpet. The building is rustic, made in the style of a log cabin. The logs are painted brown. In the center of a building is a single doorway with two paned windows on either side. To the right of the door when facing the front door, there's a sign kiosk with maps and a bulletin case. Next to the kiosk is a pay phone. To the left of the building is a restroom, painted in the same color of brown.

description: The Robert J. Lagomarsino Visitor Center at Channel Islands National Park features a bookstore, a display of marine aquatic life, and exhibits featuring the unique character of each park island. Visitors also will enjoy the 25-minute park movie, “A Treasure in the Sea,” shown throughout the day in the auditorium (closed-caption film available upon request). The fully accessible visitor center is open 8:30 am until 5 pm daily. The visitor center is closed on Thanksgiving and December 25th.
audioDescription: The Channel Islands National Park Visitor Center Building description: The Robert J. Lagomarsino Visitor Center sits at the tip of the Ventura Harbor. Surrounded by water, this striking two-story gray building has open air exhibits spaces, balconies, an outdoor amphitheater area and viewing tower. A live tidal pool with daily talks and exhibits encompass the unique character of each park island. The four-story viewing tower is embellished with artistically cut metalwork in a green patina of kelp, fish and a pelican. The tower interior offers exhibits and views of Ventura Harbor, the Channel Islands, and the Ventura coastline. The Center’s interior exhibits have several marine and Channel Islands related educational displays including a rocky tidepool, elephant seal exhibit and pygmy mammoth exhibit. There is also a theatre, and Information Center.

passportStampImages.altText: graphic image of circle with text inside that states channel islands national park virtual visit ven

directionsInfo: The visitor center is located in the Ventura Harbor in Ventura, California. Ventura is located 70 miles north of Los Angeles and 30 miles south of Santa Barbara. Plane, train, and bus service are all available to Los Angeles and Santa Barbara. Only train, bus, and private car transportation are available from Los Angeles and Santa Barbara to Ventura.

operatingHours.description: The visitor center is open 8:30 am until 5 pm daily. The visitor center is closed on Thanksgiving and December 25th.

description: Near the South Entrance to Joshua Tree National Park. Exhibits, bookstore, water, and flush toilets onsite. Picnic area nearby.
audioDescription: The Cottonwood Visitor Center sits on a high desert plateau in the transition zone between the Mojave and Colorado deserts. To the northeast, Eagle Mountain stands lofty as a rugged backdrop. Weather can be extreme. Summers are blistering, with bright sunny weather and temperatures exceeding 100 degrees daily. Winters are cool to cold, with strong winds and sub-freezing nights. Snow is possible. The occasional rainstorm poses the threat of flash flooding. There is abundant flora and fauna nearby. Desert wilderness surrounds the visitor center. Around the building we find short desert plants. There are cacti and various flora with thorns and sharp points. Cat’s-claw acacia and many of the shrubs can be unforgiving if brushed up against. There are also plants native to the Mojave, such as yucca, juniper, and sage. In spring, red berries appear on the purple bush. Prince’s Plume are adorned with yellow flowers. The ironwood trees near the Bajada Nature Trail sprout pink and purple flowers. After a rain, the Ocotillo grow red flowers and green leaves. The Prince's Plume, ironwood trees, and Ocotillo are native to the Colorado desert. Gambel’s Quail call out throughout the day, often scurrying around the parking lot. Mule deer, coyotes, and even bighorn sheep frequent the nearby landscape. Throughout the day ravens and turkey vultures soar overheard. Black-tailed jackrabbits nervously hop along, as a red-tail hawk eyes it’s next prey from the sky. In the warmer months, rattlesnakes and desert tortoise roam the nearby sandy trails. There are three one-story buildings that comprise the visitor center facilities: The visitor center, a restroom, and a staff office. From the parking area, the visitor center is located to the left. The restroom is situated to the right of the visitor center and 30 feet across from the parking lot. The men’s restroom is located on the left side of this building, and the women’s restroom is located on the right side. There are picnic tables and bulletin boards between the restrooms and the office to the right. The visitor center also serves as a gift shop and fee-entrance station. The door is located on the south side of the building. As you enter, there is a brochure table 6 feet from the inside of the door. On the right side of the building you will see interpretive panels with information about the geology, history, and geography of Joshua Tree National Park. On the walls on the south and east side of the building are panels with quotes about the park. This side also has displays with merchandise sold by the Joshua Tree National Park Association. The front counter is 25 feet from the door where you can buy park passes and merchandise. A window on the west side of the building that has been modified to receive payments for entrance fees, directly to the left of the front counter. Plexiglass hangs around the front counter for the protection of staff and visitors. The building has standard lighting and when the blinds are up, the outside sun provides ample illumination. To the right of the front counter there are more displays for merchandise. On the east wall, there is a window with a majestic view of Eagle Mountain, Mastodon Peak, and the surrounding desert. South of this window there is a bookcase with various publications on Joshua Tree National Park. In the center of the visitor center there is a life-sized mold of a desert tortoise enclosed in glass. On the west side, to the left of the brochure table, there is a window. Next to this window there is a fold-out sign that says “Encuentra Tu Parque” (“Find your Park” in Spanish). There are more store displays as you make your way closer to the front counter. There is a small, slightly shaded courtyard in-between the visitor center and the offices. There are creosote bush and beavertail cactus in the middle. A small bench is located about 10 feet to the north of the offices. There is also a bulletin with park information, maps, and trail guides. All facilities are accessible through paved and level walkways. Outside of the visitor center, there are sidewalks between the parking lot and the buildings. The parking lot has 2 handicapped spaces, with accessible ramps and paved paths to the visitor center, restroom, and office. The office is restricted to park staff and those with authorization to enter. To the right of this building is a flagpole and a sign showing air quality and fire danger. There is also a sign that displays fees to enter the park. There is a short tenth of a mile dirt nature trail that is immediately east of the visitor center. The trail is a loop that starts a few feet from the paved path that leads to the main entrance. It ends on the east side of the parking lot. There are signs along the way identifying various plants and shrubs that can be found in the area. Park rangers here every day to answer questions and provide guidance into Joshua Tree National Park.

description: Explore the history of Cesar Chavez and the farmworker movement. Originally built in 1914, the visitor center was entirely rebuilt in 2003. Inside, watch films about Cesar’s life, contemplate his office, and view exhibits that tell the story of the boycotts and marches that began the farmworker movement, and of the people who united to work for human rights. The visitor center has an auditorium that has hosted naturalization ceremonies, and a store that offers books and souvenirs. There is no entrance fee.
audioDescription: A concrete pathway turns left and then ends at the entrance of a handsome wooden building. The wood siding is painted white and windows along the front are divided into many panes. Trees and shrubs provide shade all around the building. A small flag features a portrait of Cesar Chavez and reads, "Sí, Se Puede." An arrowhead-shaped wooden sign, the logo for the National Park Service, is mounted on the building next to the flag. Wooden double doors lead into the building. A receptacle for trash and cigarettes is just to the right of the doors. Inside, a sign points toward restrooms on the right side of the entrance. A drinking fountain is in the restroom corridor.

description: The Devils Postpile Ranger Station is open daily from 9 am - 5 pm during the operating season which is typically mid-June to mid-October. Rangers can help you plan your adventure at Devils Postpile. The ranger station is listed on the National Register of Historic Places for its association with changes in national park planning and development from the late 1930s to the start of World War II in 1941. The simple two-room cabin was constructed in 1941 from lumber salvaged from the demolished Sentinel Hotel.
directionsInfo: Shuttle Bus: Most visitors must park at the Mammoth Mountain Ski Area and use the mandatory shuttle. The shuttle bus operates from mid-June through the Wednesday after Labor Day. By car: From U.S. Highway 395, drive 10 miles west on S.R. 203 to Minaret Vista and then another 8 miles on a paved, steep mountain road. Please note that this road is single lane for approximately 3 miles. By plane: The closest commercial airport is the Mammoth Lakes/Yosemite Airport (MMH), located on U.S. Highway 395.

operatingHours.description: During the operating season, the ranger station is open 7 days a week from 9:00 am to 5:00 pm.

description: The visitor center is part of the Eugene O'Neill NHS. Due to the location and nature of the park, the visitor center is accessible as part of a reservations only tour. There is a small bookstore on site.

directionsInfo: Due to the nature of Eugene O'Neill NHS, visitors are not able to drive directly to the park site. Instead, reservations are required and we offer a free shuttle that will pick up the visitor in downtown Danville, CA. The shuttle meets at 205 Railroad Avenue in downtown Danville, just outside the Museum of the San Ramon Valley. Parking is available next to the museum. More information will be given once you call and make a reservation with the park staff.

operatingHours.description: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site is only accessible by National Park Service Shuttle. Visitors are not permitted to drive their personal/private vehicles to the site. Advance reservations are required for tours on Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Sunday (no reservations required on Saturday). Tours are offered Wednesday-Sunday at either 10:00 am or 2:00 pm. Allow 2 hours for your visit. Reservations can be made by calling (925)-228-8860 X6422 .Office hours are Wednesday - Sunday from 9am to 5pm.
operatingHours.name: Eugene O'Neill National Historic Site

description: This visitor center is one mile past the Ash Mountain entrance station along the Generals Highway. Stop here for information, maps, books, gifts, and restrooms. Browse exhibits about the ecology and human history of the foothills, and join a free ranger-led program.
audioDescription: The Foothills Visitor Center building is a Mid-Century Modern design. It is a one story, rectangular building with masonry, glass, and yellow-paneled walls. On one side is an extension in light yellow stucco. The main building has a low pitched gabled roof with wide overhanging eaves that shade the concrete walkway to the entrance doors. A masonry wall across from the main entrance creates a hallway to the restrooms. On front of the building from left to right: The National Park Service Emblem, in the shape of a brown arrowhead, pointed downward. Inside the arrowhead are the words in white lettering, “National Park Service” with a green sequoia tree shape to its left. Near the bottom of the arrowhead is a white buffalo silhouette set against a green meadow, with a white lake and snowcapped mountain behind it. A tall, narrow window with a yellow panel runs from the ground to the roof’s peak. Next to it is the Foothills Visitor Center Sign, with the words, “Foothills Visitor Center” and a colorful illustration of the head and shoulders of a quail, shown in profile. Its head is brown with a small pointed beak. The crown of the quail’s head has a curved black top knot that curls forward. A black and white streak curves behind the eye and along the black neck. The neck has rows of blue and black crescent shaped “feathers”. The shoulders are brown, and the breast is blue and brown. Behind the quail is the faint outline of a light green silhouette of yucca plant, with a spiky ball of leaves at the base, and a single tall spire of flowers, rising like a plume above it.

description: Furnace Creek Visitor Center is the central hub for all things Death Valley. Here you can pay the park entrance fee, speak with a ranger about trip plans or questions, participate in the Junior Ranger program, watch the 20-minute park film, explore museum displays, and browse the park bookstore.
audioDescription: Large single-story building with covered walkway leading to entrance. Entrance is through two sets of double swinging glass doors. Directly ahead is a recessed wooden information desk, staffed by rangers, where visitors can pay fees and receive information. To the right is a museum with display topics including wildlife, human history, dark skies, climate/weather, and geology. To the left is a large table topographic map of the Death Valley area. Beyond the map are shelves and tables with merchandise (clothing, books, and educational souvenirs), sold by the non-profit park bookstore, Death Valley Natural History Association. Large double doors lead from the bookstore to an auditorium with seating, a stage, and a projector screen.

description: The museum is housed in a historic market in the Giant Forest sequoia grove at 6,500 feet (1,980 m) elevation. Explore exhibits about sequoias and learn why this landscape grows the biggest of big trees. Stop here before you explore the grove. During wilderness permit non-quota season, permits can be picked up at a self-issue station outside the museum.
audioDescription: You are on a plaza just outside of The Giant Forest Museum building. It is a long single story wooden building with a peaked roof. The structure is built with tongue and groove wooden posts and beams visible on the exterior of the building. Each end has a forward facing peaked roof and over the center of the building facing the plaza is a gabled roof with six windows. An engraved wooden sign hangs from the gabled roof. It reads, “Giant Forest Museum”. The building has brown planked wood siding. There are six wooden double doors spread along the length of the building. Above them are a row of small paned transom windows. Between each set of doors are larger multi-paned windows, with mullions and frames painted light green. On the ground outside, below each large window, is a crescent shaped stone ledge at curb height. The entrance is through the first set of double doors as you cross the road from the parking area and enter the plaza. There is a post with a handicap press pad on the stone ledge to the right of the entrance doors. The doors open outward. Above the door frame, the hours are posted.

description: The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located in downtown Twentynine Palms and features educational exhibits, a bookstore and giftshop, and visitor information.
audioDescription: The Joshua Tree National Park Visitor Center is located south of highway 62, by about half a block on Freedom Way. The building is surrounded by parking spaces and walkways on all sides. The visitor center is in the middle of the town of Twentynine Palms. There are other buildings in sight as well as sparse desert vegetation. To the south the mountains in the north boundary of Joshua Tree National Park can be seen. The visitor center itself is a dark tan, single-story building. There is a flag pole and shade structure near the front of the building facing highway 62. The parking spaces on the northside of the building are the closest to the front door and there are a few handicap parking spaces. There is a sidewalk surrounding the building.

description: The first stop for park visitors headed towards the West Entrance. Located in the village of Joshua Tree on Park Blvd. just south of Hwy 62. Exhibits, bookstore, cafe, flush toilets onsite; public telephone and showers nearby.
audioDescription: Joshua Tree Visitor Center is located outside the park in the village of Joshua Tree, population 8,000. It is five miles north of the West Entrance on Park Boulevard close to where Park Boulevard and Highway 62 intersect. From the intersection, heading south on Park Boulevard, the visitor center is on the right. The gravel parking lot, just south of the visitor center, can comfortably fit 40 cars. There is a curved cinder block wall that divides the parking lot from the visitor center. From the parking lot, there is a cement sidewalk leading a short distance through a modest cactus garden and ends at a small cement courtyard in front of the visitor center on the east side of the building. In the garden stands a flagpole and a rusted metal sculpture. The exterior of the single-story visitor center has walls that resemble corrugated metal. From the courtyard, another short cement sidewalk leads through a large wooden gate into an outdoor patio between the cinder block wall and the south side of the building. The patio is enclosed on its south end by the previously mentioned cinder block wall. Inside the patio, the ground is dirt and slopes down from the cinder block wall towards the double glass doors that lead into the visitor center. Two tables are on the patio near the doors where rangers can help visitors with information. Once entering the building, there is a one-room exhibit area with panels depicting geology, ecology, and history of Joshua Tree National Park. There is a life-sized replica of a Joshua tree accompanied with panels about the Joshua tree. There is a guitar and a U2 record album on display that represents the creative aspects of Joshua Tree National Park. There is a television that plays a 2-minute video about the park’s geology. The exhibit opens into the one-room bookstore. On display are souvenirs—stickers, patches, t-shirts, hats, stuffed animals, mugs, postcards, and books. On the side of the bookstore closest to the exhibit is a counter with three cash registers. Opposite the counter, on the north side, are two doors that open directly into the men’s and women’s bathrooms. Exit through the bookstore's double glass doors back to the courtyard on the east side of the visitor center. The northernmost section of the building, with a single glass door that opens out into the courtyard, is a cafe.

description: Originally opened in 1924 as a train station, Kelso Depot was renovated and reopened in 2005 a Visitor Center for Mojave National Preserve. Former dormitory rooms contain exhibits describing the cultural and natural history of the surrounding desert. The baggage room, ticket office and two dormitory rooms have been furnished to illustrate depot life during the first half of the twentieth century. A 20-minute orientation film is shown in the theater. Note: Kelso Depot is currently closed for repairs.

Please plan ahead as the nearest restroom facilities will be at Kelso Dunes, Baker, California and Primm, Nevada.

description: Located at beautiful Drakes Beach, the Kenneth C. Patrick Visitor Center contains exhibits that focus on maritime exploration in the 1500s, marine fossils, and marine environments. A minke whale skeleton is suspended from the ceiling. Allow 20–30 minutes to view exhibits. Park- and ocean-themed books, guides, and postcards, and maps, along with coffee and packaged snacks are for sale in the PRNSA bookstore adjacent to the Kenneth C. Patrick Visitor Center.
audioDescription: The Kenneth C. Patrick Visitor Center is located within the western arm of a large one-story, elevated building made of wood adjacent to Drakes Beach. A bookstore and restrooms are also part of this building. A large parking lot is located to the visitor center’s west. To both the east and west of the parking lot and visitor center complex, the land rises steeply to over 80 feet (25 meters) in height and then plateaus. Coastal grasslands and coastal scrub cover the land. To the south of the parking lot is a sandy beach, beyond which is Drakes Bay. Within the visitor center is an information desk and exhibits that focus on 1500s maritime exploration, marine fossils, and marine environments. A minke whale skeleton is suspended from the ceiling in the center of the exhibits.
passportStampLocationDescription: The Point Reyes National Seashore passport stamp is available at the Kenneth C. Patrick Visitor Center's information desk when the visitor center is open. If the visitor center is closed but the adjacent Point Reyes National Seashore Association's bookstore is open, the passport stamp is available inside the bookstore. If both are closed (i.e., you are visiting on a weekday), the passport stamp is also available at the Bear Valley Visitor Center. Check operating hours to know when to arrive.

emailAddresses.description:
Please browse through Point Reyes National Seashore's website (the Plan Your Visit section is very useful) and check out the Frequently Asked Questions before submitting your message. We receive a lot of emails requesting information that is available through our website.

We will respond to emails in the order they are received as soon as possible. Due to the high volume of email, response to your message may take more than a week. Please ensure that the email address you provide is correct.

Turn left and follow Bear Valley Rd. 1.75 miles (2.8 km) northwest to Sir Francis Drake Blvd. Turn left and follow Sir Francis Drake Blvd. 13.4 miles (21.4 km) west to Drakes Beach Rd. Tip: Follow road signs for “Lighthouse” until you see a sign for Drakes Beach. Turn left and follow Drakes Beach Rd. 1.6 miles (2.6 km) south to the Drakes Beach parking lot. Allow 30 minutes for the drive from Bear Valley.

description: This visitor center is in Grant Grove Village at an elevation of 6,500 feet (1,980 m). Learn about three regions in Kings Canyon National Park: giant sequoia groves, Kings Canyon, and the High Sierra. Watch a 15-minute movie (English/Spanish). A park store sells books, maps, and educational materials.
audioDescription: Kings Canyon Visitor Center is a single story wooden building with a peaked roof, made of corrugated metal. The building has brown, planked wood siding with bulletin boards and windows. The roof extends over the entrance door, supported by thick wooden beams and posts. The lobby and double entrance doors are glass and open outward. On the wall, adjacent to the entrance, metal lettering mounted on the building reads, “Visitor Center”. Below it is the National Park Service logo, in the shape of an orange arrowhead, pointed downward. Inside the arrowhead are the words in white lettering, “National Park Service” with a green sequoia tree shape to its left. Near the bottom of the arrowhead is a white buffalo silhouette set against a green meadow, with a white lake and snowcapped mountain behind it. A tall flagpole is on the right side of the visitor center. Along the building, to the left of the entrance, is a walkway under the eaves, where the restrooms, water fountain, and bulletin boards are located. A square framed wooden planter in front of the restrooms provides low seating around the native shrubs planted inside.

description: This year-round visitor center is located one mile from the Southwest Entrance. The visitor center offers an information desk, exhibit hall, auditorium, amphitheater, park store, dining area with fireplace, patio, and a gift shop and cafe. Free Wi-Fi is available inside.
audioDescription: This one-story, wooden building is nestled on the edge of a mountain valley lined by conifer forests and jagged mountain peaks. Most visitors enter through a large triangular overhang at the front entrance, which opens into a small 24-hour vestibule. A family, mens', and womens' restroom are located to the left. Two sets of double doors continue straight into the main building. Rangers provide information at an information desk at the right and notify visitors of the start of the 20-minute park film in the auditorium accessed through the doors to the left of the desk. In the center of the main room is a 3-D relief map of the park with buttons that indicate the four types of volcanoes in the park. To the immediate left of the map is a small, L-shaped park store. On the far side of the map is a doorway that opens to the back patio. To the right of the doorway is an interactive sandbox exhibit. The remainder of the rectangular building extends to the left and right of the map. The left wing of the building includes a seating indoor, fireplace, gift shop, cafe, and an exit to a service parking area. The right wing of the building includes a circular exhibit hall and an emergency exit in the far corner. The exhibit area includes an inner circle with volcanology interactive exhibits and an outer circle with text-based natural and cultural history exhibits. Within the outer circle are two smaller free-standing, cylindrical displays featuring interactive exhibits designed for young visitors.
passportStampLocationDescription: Passport stamp is located in the park store, to the left of the relief map.

operatingHours.description:
Lands End Lookout is open 7 days a week 9am to 5pm. 

At the northwestern corner of San Francisco, there is wild and windy trail with stunning views at every turn... Lands End's trails winds their way around rocky cliffs above the ocean, moving through shady stands of cypress and eucalyptus and emerging on to spectacular views of the shore, headlands, and Golden Gate. A trip down the trail is also a journey through the history of Lands End, offering glimpses of the past at every turn.

An entrance station is located at the north end of the park, but is only open in the summer. As you drive through the park you can find information kiosks with park maps at Petroglyph Point, and Gillem's Camp.

directionsInfo: Lava Beds is truly a remote park, in a corner of California most people never visit. Most roads into this area wind through mountains and along rivers, and travel may take longer than expected. Services are few and far between, and winter driving conditions can be encountered any time between fall and spring. Remember to Plan Ahead - There is no gas available at Lava Beds. We encourage you to top your tank off in one of the nearby communities of Klamath Falls, OR, Merrill, OR, Tulelake, CA, or Alturas, CA.

description: Located in the conifer zone at an elevation of 6,700 feet (2,040 m), the visitor center provides opportunities to view exhibits, get trip planning advice, get a wilderness permit, watch several park films, or shop at the gift shop. New exhibits immerse visitors in the wilderness environments of the parks, from the foothills to the highest peaks and to underground caves, as well as exploring the human history of the southern Sierra Nevada with tactile exhibits and soundscapes from every park environment.
audioDescription: You are standing on a paved courtyard with low stone edging and wood benches, around the low grass and conifer trees that landscape Lodgepole Visitor Center. Adjacent to the entrance is a large granite rock with a plaque on a grassy area. Lodgepole Visitor Center is a single story wooden building with a high peaked roof, made of corrugated metal. The building has brown, planked wood siding with bulletin boards and windows. The double entrance doors open outward. There is an additional peaked roof over the entrance door, supported by large wooden posts and beams. Along the building, to both the left and right of the entrance, is a low stone border that creates a walkway under the eaves of the roof. Centered under the entrance roof is an embossed wood sign over the door. It reads, “Visitor Center”. Above it is the National Park Service logo, in the shape of a brown arrowhead, pointed downward. Inside the arrowhead are the words in white lettering, “National Park Service” with a green sequoia tree shape to its left. Near the bottom of the arrowhead is a white buffalo silhouette set against a green meadow, with a white lake and snowcapped mountain behind it. To reach the restrooms, follow the covered walkway to the right of the entrance doors. The restrooms are at the end of the building.

description: The historic museum is located one mile from the northwest entrance of the park near Manzanita Lake. The museum is only open during the summer months. Visit for information, to view exhibits and the park film, shop at the park store, or participate in a ranger-led program (offered primarily outside in the adjacent Loomis Plaza). From the museum you can pick up the trail around Manzanita Lake or cross the highway to access the self-guided, interpretive Lily Pond Nature Trail.
audioDescription: This single-story building is built of native volcanic rock and surrounded by a three-foot-high rock wall. A set of steps leads to the front entrance, which opens into a large exhibit hall. An information desk and is located in the corner to the right and a park store is located in a corner to the left. A set of glass exhibit cases sit in the center of the room creating a circular walkway through exhibits on both sides. A doorway at the back of the hall leads down a short hallway to an auditorium where the park film is shown. The hallway ends at a wheelchair accessible entrance that exits to a ramp that wraps around the building and back to the front entrance. The museum sits on the west edge of a plaza, which includes a small restroom building and a second single story building that serves as a ranger station.

description: The Manzanar visitor center offers extensive exhibits, a 22-minute park film, a bookstore, a Junior Ranger program, and an information desk.
audioDescription: The visitor center is located some distance from the highway, frontage road, and parking lot. It is in the high desert and as you approach from the parking lot, the high Sierra stand behind the visitor center. The visitor entrance is on the left front of the building, up a ramp or stairs. The building is quite large and tall, but it is navigable on one floor. The building was once the Manzanar High School Auditorium. You are entering from the back of the historic building.

description: Located in a mixed-conifer forest at 7,600 feet (2,320 m), the Mineral King Ranger Station houses some exhibits on Mineral King's human and natural history. Books, maps, and educational items for sale. Food storage canisters are available. Obtain wilderness permits here. Planning to park overnight? Marmots may attempt to get in your car's undercarriage or damage wiring. Make sure that you wrap the underside of your vehicle in a tarp.
audioDescription: When you reach Mineral King Ranger Station there are two parking areas, the first is in front of the ranger station. It has an orientation kiosk, directions to the Campfire circle and restrooms. The second parking area is across the road. It has a smaller wood framed building with a Bear Safety exhibit. There are two metal bear storage lockers. There is a creek running by this lot. Picnic tables are next to the creek so it is a shady place to stop and rest. In front of the Ranger Station is a stone border, behind it, six stairs lead up to the deck of the Ranger Station. On the deck is a wayside exhibit about local trails, and a flagpole, flying the U.S. flag. The Station itself is a single-story cabin-style wooden building with a peaked roof. It has reddish brown planked wood siding. Large wooden joists support the roof. The entrance door is covered by a smaller overhanging roof, supported by rustic wooden posts and beams, with an embossed wooden sign over the door that reads, “Mineral King Ranger Station Elevation: 7,580 Ft.”. Posted beside the entrance door are a variety of notices. There are windows on either side of the door. High on the wall, is the National Park Service logo, in the shape of a brown arrowhead, pointed downward. Inside the arrowhead are the words in white lettering, “National Park Service” with a green sequoia tree shape to its left. Near the bottom of the arrowhead is a white buffalo silhouette set against a green meadow, with a white lake and snowcapped mountain behind it.

description: This visitor center has permanently closed. The native gardens, outdoor art displays, restroom facilities, and Oasis of Mara trail remain open to the public.
audioDescription: The Oasis Visitor Center sits at the corner of National Park Drive and Utah Trail. These roads surround the building on the south and east sides. A large parking lot with access to the front entrance of the visitor center is also located at the intersection of these roads. To the west, the Oasis of Mara is scattered with California fan palm trees and other desert plants. To the north of Oasis Visitor Center lies the Park Headquarters building. The visitor center itself is a pale-yellow, single-story building with green and red roofing. The parking lot to the east side leads to the entrance on a sidewalk. Along the right side of the pathway, also on the east side, visitors will find an entrance to a courtyard. On the east side of the courtyard, there are restrooms, a women’s restroom on the right and a men’s restroom on the left. In the center of the courtyard, there is a drinking fountain and water refill station. On the north side of the pathway, there is a garden running along the side of the building filled with native desert plants and a geo-kinetic metal art structure. This sculpture contains two large circles with animals that slowly move in the wind. The pathway also leads to the visitor center doors. The main Oasis Visitor Center entrance is closest to the parking lot. Visitors walking from the parking lot will find the main entrance on their right. The main entrance consists of glass double doors that open outward. The other entrance to the visitor center is a few steps away, around the corner on the west side of the building. This side entrance is a single glass door that opens outward. The pathway continues past both doors and to a patio with several picnic tables. The back patio leads to the Oasis of Mara Nature Trail. Both entrances open-up to a shop that sells books and other souvenirs. Straight ahead from the main entrance is the register where one can purchase their souvenirs or a pass to enter the park. On the right-hand side of the registers, the visitor center opens into another room filled with educational exhibits about the ecology, geology, and history of the park.

description: The small Outdoors Santa Barbara Visitor Center not only has one of the best views of Santa Barbara, but also offers visitors information about Channel Islands National Park, Channel Islands National Marine Sanctuary, Santa Barbara Maritime Museum, and the City of Santa Barbara. Open 10:30 am until 4:30 pm daily. The visitor center is closed on Thanksgiving Day, December 25, January 1, and the first Friday in August for Fiesta.
audioDescription: Located in the bustling Waterfront of Santa Barbara's working harbor, the visitor center offers one of the best views of the city, beaches, harbor, mountains, wharf and islands. Stepping inside the visitor center there are interpretive displays about Chumash culture, Spanish explorers, Missionaries and American Ranchers. A spectacular mosaic tiled floor showing the Channel Islands and the Marine Sanctuary, the Rainbow Bridge legend and flowers native to the islands. An underwater kelp forest mural delights visitors who are curious about the marine life that inhabits our park and marine sanctuary. Garabaldi, tiger sharks, sea stars, lobster, abalone, and urchins are just a few of the species found in the kelp forest mural. Numerous free brochures and reference materials about the forest, park, sanctuary and the city of Santa Barbara are available for the visitor. A computer screen displays websites of all four agencies for ease in accessing updated information. Our outside deck has several interpretive displays about the park, the sanctuary and the forest. A telescope is setup for viewing wildlife and the visitor will find comfortable benches to sit and enjoy the spectacular views from the fourth floor deck.
directionsInfo: The Outdoors Santa Barbara Visitor Center is located in the Santa Barbara Harbor in Santa Barbara, California. Santa Barbara is located 100 miles north of Los Angeles and 30 miles north of Ventura. Plane, train, and bus service are all available to Los Angeles and Santa Barbara.

description: The Lighthouse Visitor Center (LHVC) offers exhibits on the Point Reyes Lighthouse, marine life, & maritime history, as well as a small bookstore. The stairs down to the lighthouse are only open when the LHVC is open and wind speeds remain below 40 mph (64km/h). The Observation Deck at the top of the stairs is open daily from 6 am to ~11:45 pm and offers a great view on a clear day.
audioDescription: The Lighthouse Visitor Center is a smallish white-sided, brown-shingled building with two wings near the western end of a narrow high rocky headland surrounded by the Pacific Ocean. A rocky knoll rises above the building to its west. A large concrete-covered watershed is to the south of the path that leads to and beyond the visitor center. Within the visitor center are exhibits about the historic Point Reyes Lighthouse, as well as on whales, seals and sea lions, wildflowers, birds and maritime history. A touch table allows visitors to feel baleen and to closely inspect the skulls of various marine mammals. The Fresnel lens from the San Francisco Lightship is also on display. Attached to the Lighthouse Visitor Center is the Ocean Exploration Center, which highlights the spectacularly rich and globally significant ocean environment of North-central California. The Ocean Exploration Center features 3-D models of a California sea lion, a Dall's porpoise, a sooty shearwater, and a white shark suspended from the ceiling, murals depicting life below the surface painted on the walls, and informative panels describing ocean wildlife and habitats off our coast. A large picture window offers visitors a stunning view of the Point Reyes Beach and the Pacific Ocean, while protecting them from the legendary winds of Point Reyes.
passportStampLocationDescription: The Point Reyes National Seashore passport stamp is available at the Lighthouse Visitor Center's information desk, if the visitor center is open. If the Lighthouse Visitor Center is closed, the passport stamp is also available at the Bear Valley Visitor Center. Please check the Bear Valley Visitor Center's operating hours to know when to arrive.

emailAddresses.description:
Please browse through Point Reyes National Seashore's website (the Plan Your Visit section is very useful) and check out the Frequently Asked Questions before submitting your message. We receive a lot of emails requesting information that is available through our website.

We will respond to emails in the order they are received as soon as possible. Due to the high volume of email, response to your message may take more than a week. Please ensure that the email address you provide is correct.

directionsInfo: From the Bear Valley Visitor Center (BVVC), head north 0.2 miles (0.3 km) to Bear Valley Rd. Turn left and follow Bear Valley Rd. 1.75 miles (2.8 km) northwest to Sir Francis Drake Blvd. Turn left and follow Sir Francis Drake Blvd. 18.7 miles (29.9 km) west to the Point Reyes Lighthouse visitor parking lot. To get to the Lighthouse and Visitor Center from the visitors' parking lot, walk past the gate and continue west 0.4 miles (0.6 km). Allow 45 minutes for the drive from the BVVC.

operatingHours.description: The Lighthouse Visitor Center (LHVC) & the stairs leading down to the lighthouse (LH) are open from 10 am to 4 pm on Saturdays through Mondays (provided there are no active exceptions) & closed Tue–Fri. The stairs to the LH are closed when winds exceed 40 miles per hour. The LH's clockwork room, which houses the original clockworks & from which one can get a close look at the first-order Fresnel lens, is usually open on days the stairs are open from 1:30 pm to 3:30 pm, as staffing, COVID, & weather permit.

description: Located just off the Newton B. Drury Scenic Parkway - in the heart of Prairie Creek Redwoods State Park. Exhibits about the Civilian Conservation Corps and redwood ecology, park information, junior ranger program, bookstore and retail sales.
audioDescription: Historic 1930's building that looks like a cabin. It is single story and set in front of towering redwood trees. The 300-foot trees make the visitor center look small. Porch and steps/ramp in front. There are a handful of 20-minute parking spots in front. Picnic tables, interpretive panels, trail-head information, water faucet and additional parking spots are 100-400 feet from the building.

description: The visitor contact and ranger station is only open when staff is present.
audioDescription:
In an open field, next to the airplane landing strip, sits the ranger station. It is an L-shaped wooden building. The building has brown, planked wood siding. If facing the front of the building, four upper, clerestory windows are visible near the peak of the roof. A lower roof overhangs the front of the building, supported by beams and posts, creating a covered walkway. Along that walkway, at ground level, five windows alternate with five doors. Two wooden benches along the exterior wall provide seating. At the bend of the L-shape is a 10-foot by 10-foot structure that sticks up about 10 feet taller than the roof. Sticking up from it are several tall rods and a shallow, concave-shaped satellite dish. An outdoor lamp attached to the side.

In front of the station is a picnic table and a flagpole, flying the United States flag. On the left side of the walkway is a low wire frame platform. Mounted on top of this is a large brush, made of stiff blue plastic spikes, used to clean off the bottoms of boots. Further to the left is a small, single-seater wood plank outhouse, with symbols on the door representing both a man and a woman. Several other small storage sheds are nearby.The ranger station information center is through the second door from the right. The room is a large and open space, with high ceilings. It has light wood paneling. Windows line the back wall behind a partially-partitioned area with desks and a table with two chairs. Colorful pictures on the walls display island views. On the left side of the room are two doors leading to equipment and supply closets. To the right is a television, set on the top of a corner cabinet, with a shelf of videos below it.

description: A small visitor center is located on the island. Features include displays on the natural and cultural resources of the island.
audioDescription:
If you are standing at the flagpole, facing the Santa Barbara Island Visitor Center, you are on a high bluff, and the ocean is far below, on your left. You are in the middle of a coreopsis forest. Depending on the season, the coreopsis, with a thick, bare trunk, topped by a shaggy mop of yellow flowers and feathery green leaves, shaped like fluffy ostrich feathers. In late summer, fall or winter, the coreopsis will turn into waist-high brown stalks that look dead.

The single-story beige building, has a roof made of overlapping curved red tiles. On the wall, facing you, are two wooden signs with white lettering. The one on the ocean side reads, "Visitor Center." The one on the land side reads, "Private Residence." Between the signs are two narrow vertical windows. Below the windows, running the length of the building are several dense shrubs. An open patio extends out on the ocean side of the building, but watch your step, as it is about ten inches above ground. Just off this patio is the door to the visitor center and a tall window with a view into the exhibit. The patio has a picnic table and an outdoor panel about sea bird habitat, described separately. Beyond this first patio is another, gated, patio, blocked by a brick wall. On the opposite side of building-the "Private Residence" side- is a walkway running the length of the building.

description: The historic schoolhouse is now home to this small visitor contact station with exhibits on the ranching history of Santa Rosa Island.
audioDescription: Standing in the doorway of the school house facing inward, the interior is about 16 feet long and 8 feet wide. The walls and ceiling are finished with narrow vertical wooden slat paneling, painted white. The ceiling has a framed inset panel, to access the attic, and a white ceramic ceiling lamp, with a brass mount. The wooden plank floor has a glossy polish. Moving into the room, along the left wall, you will find a framed window with thin wooden mullions containing 12 glass panes; a mounted metal box; a clear plastic pamphlet holder; an information panel; two larger exhibit panels with a low wooden green bench below them; six exhibits with large photographs; and a wall plaque that reads,AcknowledgementsImages of Santa Cruz Island, Santa Rosa Island and Nuestra Senora del RefugioCommemorating Early Land Grants on Both Sides of the ChannelAn exhibition organized by the Santa Barbara Trust for Historic PreservationExhibition Sponsors: The Henry W. Bull FoundationCurators: Carol Storke, Anne Petersen, Curator. SBTHPCuratorial Assistant: Amanda WillifordPhotography and Printing: William B. DeweyGraphic Design: Mary KirkPatrick, Clearview StudioPrint Mounting: Ken KirkPatrick, Anacapa SignsSpecial Thanks:Chris Chapman, Manager, Arroyo Hondo Preserve; Peggy Dahl, Santa Cruz Island Foundation; Marla Daily, President, Santa Cruz Island Foundation; Neal Graffy, Elizabeth Hvolboll, Michael Redmon, Archivist, Santa Barbara Historical Society; Terri Sheridan, Archivist, Santa Barbara Museum of Natural History; Nita Vail, Executive Director, California Rangeland Trust; Kim Walters, Archivist, Southwest Museum; Lynn Weber, Curatorial Volunteer, SBTHP. Will Woolley and the staff, board and many volunteers at the Santa Barbara Trust for Historic Preservation. On the lower right corner of the plaque is the Seal of the Santa Barbara Trust Historic Preservation, a round logo, with a center illustration of an early adobe brick Spanish mission building, with a bell tower with a cross on top.Along the back wall is wooden door, and also two tall closet doors.Along the right wall, from back to front, are two windows; four exhibits with large photos; and another window with a green wooden bench below it.On the floor near the back of the room, are four wooden chairs, arranged in two rows, both facing the front door. Each has a single arm rest that extends and curves out to become a wide flat panel, parallel to the floor. The two chairs have this arm rest panel on the right "arm," and the other two have it on the left "arm."An information panel, titled "Santa Rosa Island Interpretive Guide," is posted on the wall inside the School House.The panel background is a black and white photo showing twelve people on horseback, in front of a wooden fence. Behind it is a thick section of trees. In the distance, to the left, is a large hill.The text reads,Learn more about ranch history, including a complete map and guide to the ranch area, in the Santa Rosa Island Interpretive Guide.The guide also provides detailed information on island Chumash history, military history, and natural history. In addition, it serves as a trail guide for the 1.75 mile hike from the pier to Water Canyon Beach via Cherry Canyon.Borrow the guide and return it or take it home and donate at ciparkfoundation.org/join-support/.Below and to the left of this panel is a small metal box with a locked panel in front, and a slanted top with a slit in the center, about three inches wide. To the right of this box is a wall mounted plastic holder that contains the guides. This exhibit panel, titled "Channel Island Ranchos," provides cultural history about Santa Cruz Island and Santa Rosa Island.The panel background is a faded sepia photo, in shades of brown. It shows a steep, rocky shoreline, with a wooden staircase rising from the beach to the rocky plateau above. On the plateau are a large, long building, two smaller buildings, and canvas tents. The text reads:Santa Cruz Island covers almost 61,000 acres, its fertile central valley girded by rugged mountains, reaching 2,434 feet.Santa Rosa Island encompasses over 54,000 acres, of strikingly different topography - rolling grassy hills, mesas with deep-cut arroyos, and dunes that shift in the almost continuous winds.The Early Years.Humans inhabited the Channel Islands as early as 12,000 years ago. In 1542, Juan Rodriguez Cabrillo found populous Chumash villages on Santa Cruz, Santa Rosa, and San Miguel islands. The waters of the Santa Barbara Channel teemed with marine life, and the Channel Islands were regular ports of call for fur traders, hunters, and fishermen in the late eighteenth century, although most trade was illegal under both Spanish (1769 to 1821) and Mexican (1821 to 1848) rule. The sea otter population experienced a serious decline by 1820 and the seals by 1830. By 1810 the islanders, victimized by European disease and their economy disrupted, began to migrate to the mainland at the urging of Franciscan padres.

description: Located at the southern end of the community of Newbury Park, this site reflects the heritage of both Native Americans and local ranching. The Satwiwa Native American Indian Culture Center is open on weekends from 9am to 5pm. Native American workshops and programs occur throughout the year.
directionsInfo: Main entrance - cross street is Via Goleta and Potrero Road, Newbury Park, CA, 91320. From Ventura Freeway (U.S. 101) exit Lynn Road. Turn south on Lynn Road for 5.25 miles to Via Goleta. Park Entrance is on the left. Walk 0.3 mile up gravel road from the last parking area to the Culture Center. Note: The driveway off Potrero Rd is a service road and access to handicap parking only.

description: The small visitor center resides in the historic Scorpion Ranch house which was constructed in 1886-1887.
audioDescription: On the valley floor, within the protection of a wide canyon is the Scorpion Ranch housing complex that consists of a two-story ranch house with a kitchen, bakery with a built-in masonry oven, dining area and two rooms upstairs for housing ranch staff. A bunkhouse and a storage shed, about the size of a garage, are also within the 5-foot-high wooden split rail fence that surrounds the compound. Gardens, shrubs and fig trees edge the buildings. The two-story, adobe Scorpion Ranch house, now the visitor center with exhibits, is tucked in close to the canyon walls and faces the open valley to the south. The ranch house was built in 1886 of rubble-wall masonry and rests on a stone and mortar foundation. The building has a rectangular plan that measures 51 feet by 18 feet. It has a shed roof and walls that are 20 inches thick and composed of local stone, adobe bricks, mortar covered with white stucco, and limestone. Windows across the face of the building provide natural light. The first floor has two main rooms, both are open to the public with exhibits and audio visual components that describe the natural and cultural history of the area. The bakery is at the west end of the building and also contains exhibits. The bunkhouse is located immediately south of the adobe ranch house. Built in 1914, this one-and-a-half story wood frame structure has a simple, gable-roof and white board-and-batten siding.
